t: Proverbs 16
Contrast the Upright and the Wicked
The*pn plans of the heart belong to man, But*ln the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.*s
All*ln the ways of a man are clean in his own sight, But*ln the Lord*s weighs the motives.
Commit*ln your works to the Lord*s And*ln your plans will be established.
The*ln Lord*s has made everything for its own purpose, Even*ln the wicked for the day of evil.
Everyone*ln who is proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord;*s Assuredly,*ln he will not be unpunished.
By*ln lovingkindness and truth iniquity is atoned for, And*ln by the fear of the Lord*s one keeps away from evil.
When*ln a man’s ways are pleasing to the Lord,*s He*ln makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Better*ln is a little with righteousness Than*ln great income with injustice.
The*ln mind of man plans his way, But*ln the Lord*s directs his steps.
A*ln divine decision is in the lips of the king; His*ln mouth should not err in judgment.
A*ln just balance and scales belong to the Lord;*s All*ln the weights of the bag are His concern.
It*ln is an abomination for kings to commit wicked acts, For*ln a throne is established on righteousness.
Righteous*ln lips are the delight of kings, And*ln he who speaks right is loved.
The*ln fury of a king is like*i messengers of death, But*ln a wise man will appease it.
In*ln the light of a king’s face is life, And*ln his favor is like a cloud with the spring rain.
How*ln much better it is to get wisdom than gold! And*ln to get understanding is to be chosen above silver.
The*ln highway of the upright is to depart from evil; He*ln who watches his way preserves his life.
Pride*ln goes*i before destruction, And*ln a haughty spirit before stumbling.
It*ln is better to be humble in spirit with the lowly Than*ln to divide the spoil with the proud.
He*ln who gives attention to the word will find good, And*ln blessed is he who trusts in the Lord.*s
The*ln wise in heart will be called understanding, And*ln sweetness of speech increases persuasiveness.
Understanding*ln is a fountain of life to one who has it, But*ln the discipline of fools is folly.
The*ln heart of the wise instructs his mouth And*ln adds persuasiveness to his lips.
Pleasant*ln words are a honeycomb, Sweet*ln to the soul and healing to the bones.
There*ln is a way which*i seems*i right to a man, But*ln its end is the way of death.
A*ln worker’s appetite works for him, For*ln his hunger urges him on.*i
A*ln worthless man digs up evil, While*ln his words are like scorching fire.
A*ln perverse man spreads strife, And*ln a slanderer separates intimate friends.
A*ln man of violence entices his neighbor And*ln leads him in a way that is not good.
He*ln who winks his eyes does*i so*i to devise perverse things; He*ln who compresses his lips brings evil to pass.
A*ln gray head is a crown of glory; It*ln is found in the way of righteousness.
He*ln who is slow to anger is better than the mighty, And*ln he who rules his spirit, than he who captures a city.
The*ln lot is cast into the lap, But*ln its every decision is from the Lord.*s
